page.title: 04EDINBANE SCHOOL - PAST
page.content: In the middle of the 19th Century, Macleod of Greshornish built a school for his model village, Edinbane. Two rooms accommodated a hundred children, but many missed schooling because of seasonal work; gathering whelks, herding, planting and lifting potatoes and gathering seaweed. There was a great fear of infection with a rumour of measles of scarlet fever producing a "scare" which kept children at home, although the old log book tells wryly how, during a "scare" they al turned up for the Christmas treat supplied by the doctor. Auntie Maggie MacDonald told how, about 80 years ago, she walked barefoot and carrying two peats for the fire, the four miles to school. "Often on a winter morning we would put up the cattle so that we could warm out feet on the ground where they had been lying".
